column1: Santa Cruz (; Spanish for 'Holy Cross') is the county seat and largest city of Santa Cruz County
column2: California. As of 2019 the U.S. Census Bureau estimated Santa Cruz's population at 64

column1: The present-day site of Santa Cruz was the location of Spanish settlement beginning in 1791
column2: including Mission Santa Cruz and the pueblo of Branciforte. The City of Santa Cruz was incorporated in 1866 and chartered in April 1876. Important early industries included lumber
column4: lime and agriculture. Late in the 19th century
column5: Santa Cruz established itself as a beach resort community.

column1: Prior to the arrival of Spanish soldiers
column2: missionaries and colonists in the late 18th century
column3: Santa Cruz County was home to the Awaswas Natives. The misnomer Ohlone
column4: while often used to describe the native people of the Santa Cruz area
column5: is a generalized name for the many diverse groups that lived in the region stretching from San Francisco to the Monterey Bay. The diverse and numerous tribes of this region were also earlier referred to by the Spanish as Coastanoan. The term "Ohlone" has been used in place of "Costanoan" since the 1970s by some descendant groups and by most ethnographers
column6: historians
column7: and writers of popular literature. Awaswa was one of the eight Costanoan languages and made up a tribe of Native Americans living in Western Santa Cruz County
column8: stretching slightly north of Davenport to Rio Del Mar. The Awaswas tribe was made up of no more than one thousand people and their language is now extinct.  The only remnants of their spoken language are three local place names: Aptos
column9: Soquel and Zayante; and the name of a native shellfish – abalone. The majority of Ohlone or Coastanoan tribes had no written language
column10: and lived in small villages scattered around the Monterey Bay and San Francisco Bay regions. Within fifty years of the Spaniards' arrival
column11: the Ohlone or Coastanoan culture and way of life had virtually disappeared in the Bay area. Today
column13: the Awaswa people 'missionized' in Santa Cruz and the Mutsun people 'missionized' at San Juan Bautista
column14: have joined together as the Amah Mutsan Tribal Band in an effort to protect and maintain the authentic and distinct cultural history and practices.

column2: newly independent Mexico assumed control of the area. Following the secularization of the Mission in 1834
column3: the government attempted to rename the community that had grown up around the Mission

column1: Only two ranchos were totally within the boundaries of today's city of Santa Cruz. Rancho Potrero Y Rincon de San Pedro Regalado consisted mostly of flat
column2: river-bottom pasture land north of Mission Hill ("potrero" translates as "pasture"). Rancho Tres Ojos de Agua was on the west side. Three other rancho boundaries later became part of the modern city limits: Rancho Refugio on the west. Rancho Carbonera on the north
column3: and Rancho Arroyo del Rodeo on the east.

column1: After secularization put most California land into private hands
column2: immigrants from the United States began to arrive in steadily increasing numbers

column4: following the Mexican–American War

column1: The Native Americans of Santa Cruz are known to be the Ohlone people
column2: who occupied the area from Monterey to San Francisco. The Spanish called them "Costanos".  Costanos is derived from the Spanish word costa (coast). "Ohlone" is a more recent name for the same language group. The Costanos (anglicized as "Costanoan") people spoke eight known dialects
column3: each defining a different tribelet area. During the mission era
column4: the number of native people in the Bay Area
column5: including Santa Cruz
column6: began to rapidly decrease. Many natives brought to live at the missions (neophytes) died from European diseases to which they had no resistance. As the missions closed
column7: most of the remaining neophytes living at the missions became laborers on the ranchos that inherited the former mission lands.

column1: The ancestors of the Costanoan people are thought to have originally migrated to the San Francisco and Monterey Bay Area from the San Joaquin-Sacramento River system sometime around A.D. 500. With the arrival of the Spanish
column2: the Costanoan people experienced a cultural disruption. During their time with the missions the Costanoan people experienced cultural shock
column3: mistreatment and diseases brought from Europe. In 1834
column4: 14 years after Mexico won its independence from Spain
column5: the twenty-one California missions were secularized. The vast lands they were supposed to be holding in trust for converted natives went instead mostly to friends and relatives of the Alta California government (including some foreign immigrants who had married into Californio families). The remaining Costanoan/Ohlone mission residents struggled to survive
column6: and many became servants or agricultural laborers or vaqueros (cowboys). Some small communities were formed after this which promoted old ways but in different locations from their homelands.

column1: Elihu Anthony (1818–1905) arrived in Santa Cruz
column2: California in 1847 and opened many firsts for the city of Santa Cruz; including the first Protestant Church
column4: he built the first wharf and was the first postmaster. He developed the first commercial blocks in downtown Santa Cruz with his early blacksmith foundry located at the corner of Pacific Street and Mission Street. Anthony with Frederick A. Hihn
column5: built the first private water supply network in the city and serving nearby communities. The establishment of railroad lines in Santa Cruz in 1876 until 1881 with the Santa Cruz Railroad
column6: brought workers to Santa Cruz and provided market access for the city's timber
column7: leather and limestone industries.

column1: California Powder Works began manufacturing blasting powder for California mining when normal supplies were interrupted by the American Civil War.  A powder mill built on the San Lorenzo River upstream of Santa Cruz used charcoal and powder kegs manufactured from local forests.  The mill later manufactured smokeless powder used in United States Army Krag-Jørgensen rifles and guns of the United States Navy Pacific and Asiatic fleets.  The mill was heavily damaged by a series of explosions on the evening of April 26
column2: 1898.  The explosions caused flaming debris to fall on Mission Hill and caused fires threatening the city.  The powder works employed 150 to 275 men until operations ceased in 1914.

column1: Santa Cruz was hard hit by the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake that killed three people. It was also hit by ocean surges caused by the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami
column2: wherein the Santa Cruz Small Craft Harbor sustained an estimated $10 million of damage
column3: with another $5 million of damage to docked boats there.

column2: The Resource Center for Nonviolence is one of the oldest and most centrally located non-profit organizations committed to political and social activism in Santa Cruz County. The center is "dedicated to promoting the principles of nonviolent social change and enhancing the quality of life and human dignity".  In 1998
column3: the Santa Cruz community declared itself a Nuclear-free zone
column4: and in 2003
column5: the Santa Cruz City Council became the first City Council in the U.S. to denounce the Iraq War. The City Council of Santa Cruz also issued a proclamation opposing the USA PATRIOT Act.As a center of liberal and progressive activism
column6: Santa Cruz became one of the first cities to approve marijuana for medicinal uses.  In 1992
column7: residents overwhelmingly approved Measure A
column8: which allowed for the medicinal uses of marijuana. Santa Cruz was home to the second above-ground medical marijuana club in the world when the Santa Cruz Cannabis Buyers Club opened its doors in April 1995. Santa Cruz also became one of the first cities in California to test the state's medical marijuana laws in court after the arrest of Valerie Corral and Mike Corral
column9: founders of the Wo/Men's Alliance for Medical Marijuana
column10: by the DEA. The case was ruled in favor of the growers. In 2005
column11: the Santa Cruz City Council established a city government office to assist residents with obtaining medical marijuana. On November 7
column13: the voters of Santa Cruz passed Measure K by a vote of 64–36 percent. Measure K made adult non-medical cannabis offenses the lowest priority for law enforcement; this does not apply to cultivation
column17: or driving under the influence. The measure requests the Santa Cruz city clerk send letters annually to state and federal representatives advocating reform of cannabis laws. In January 2020
column18: Santa Cruz became the third city in the US and second city in California to decriminalize psilocybin mushrooms in addition to a slew of other entheogenic plants on the Federal Schedule 1 Substance List.Notable feminist activists Nikki Craft and Ann Simonton resided in Santa Cruz
column19: where they formed the "Praying Mantis Brigade". This collection of activists organized the "Myth California Pageant" in the 1980s protesting "the objectification of women and the glorification of the beauty myth." Myth California was staged concurrently with the Miss California pageant held in Santa Cruz since the 1920s. The protests ran for nine years and eventually contributed to the Miss California pageant leaving Santa Cruz. Simonton founded and coordinates the non-profit group "Media Watch" which monitors and critiques media images of women and ethnic minorities. Beginning in 1983 Santa Cruz has hosted an annual Take Back the Night candlelight vigil
column22: and protest focusing on the issue of violence against women.Riots occurred on May 1
column24: sparked when leftist extremists threw jugs of paint at police cars and painted anarchist symbols and anti-capitalist phrases onto buildings. Property damages are estimated to top roughly $100
column26: a May Day rally was being held for worker and immigrant rights. According to police
column27: the rally was infiltrated by a local anarchists group
column28: who used the rally as a cover for attacking corporate premises. The riots started when the protesters began vandalizing nearby buildings; by 10:30 pm
column30: a dozen buildings were already vandalized. The scene then intensified when a group of about ten people began breaking storefront windows at approximately 11:05 pm. Several police officers were stationed downtown
column31: but retreated after protesters threw stones at their vehicles. After calling in backup resources from around the county
column32: law enforcement reached the riots at 11:23 pm
column34: the delay due to a large number of phony 911 calls
column35: which diverted the police force all around the county.Occupy Santa Cruz formed as an autonomous organization in solidarity with the worldwide Occupy movement
column36: a broad-based protest against economic and social inequality. Occupy Santa Cruz was most active in the fall of 2011
column37: and included over a thousand active members at its peak.  The organization gained most of its notoriety when members barricaded themselves in an empty bank building owned by Wells Fargo and occupied the building for 72 hours causing $30
column38: 000 in damages. 11 criminal charges were filed
column39: at least seven of which have since been dropped.

column4: and Capitola Electric Railroad began operations in 1881. The Union Traction Company consolidated three electric tram service routes in 1904. One line ran from DeLaveaga Park along Water Street and Pacific Avenue to the beach

column2: Pacific Avenue had become the main street of downtown Santa Cruz
column3: and remains so today. Local architect Kermit Darrow and landscape architect Roy Rydell were engaged in 1969 to convert several blocks of Pacific Avenue into a semi-pedestrian street named the Pacific Garden Mall.  The Loma Prieta earthquake of 1989 destroyed nearly all of the 19th-century buildings in the downtown area. The Pacific Avenue Historic District had been recognized by the National Register of Historic Places; it was delisted in 1991. After the earthquake
column4: the Pacific Garden Mall theme was eliminated
column5: and an updated downtown design plan by ROMA Design Group was implemented. As of 2016
column6: only one empty lot remains on Pacific Avenue from the destruction of the 1989 earthquake.

column5: Pacific Avenue serves as an outlet for the artistic and unique culture that Santa Cruz possesses.

column1: Santa Cruz is well known for watersports such as sailing
column4: stand up paddle boarding
column5: paddling
column6: and is regarded as one of the best spots in the world for surfing. It is the home of O'Neill Wetsuits and Santa Cruz Surfboards
column7: as well as Santa Cruz Skateboards and Santa Cruz Bicycles. The Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk is California's oldest amusement park and a designated State Historic Landmark. It is family-operated
column8: and celebrated its Centennial in 2007. It is home to the iconic Giant Dipper roller coaster
column9: which is currently the fifth oldest coaster in the United States. Home to a National Historic Landmark

column11: the Boardwalk has been owned and operated by the Santa Cruz Seaside Company since 1915.In one of the first published descriptions of surfing in California
column14: Prince Edward Abnel Keliʻiahonui and Prince Jonah Kalanianaʻole
column15: surfed on locally milled redwood boards at the mouth of the San Lorenzo River in July 1885. Santa Cruz has 11 world-class surf breaks
column16: including the point breaks over rock bottoms near Steamer Lane and Pleasure Point
column17: which create some of the best surfing waves in the world. The Santa Cruz Surfing Museum at Steamer Lane is staffed by docents from the Santa Cruz Surfing Club who have surfed Santa Cruz waves since the 1930s. Santa Cruz hosts several surf contests drawing international participants each year
column18: including the O'Neill Cold Water Classic

column1: The Santa Cruz Sentinel is Santa Cruz's only daily newspaper.  The area is also served by the weekly newspaper Good Times
column2: bought in 2014 by the owners of its competitor Santa Cruz Weekly
column4: continuing one paper under the Good Times name
column5: and the legal paper Santa Cruz Record.  University of California has its own publication
column6: City on a Hill Press
column7: and an alternative humor publication
column8: Fish Rap Live!. There is also an online newspaper called Santa Cruz Wire.

column4: Santa Cruz politicians tried to stop the mark from being registered by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office because of a 10-year-old controversy over Santa Cruz's nickname "Surf City." Huntington Beach has obtained a total of seven registrations for the "Surf City USA" trademark.  None of these registrations of the trademark are on the principal register
column5: but on the secondary register
column6: which means that Huntington Beach has no exclusive right to assert ownership over the "Surf City USA" trademark.  Two Santa Cruz surf shops
column7: Shoreline Surf Shop and Noland's on the Wharf
column8: sued the city of Huntington Beach in order to protect the public use of the term "Surf City."  The parties reached a confidential settlement in January 2008
column9: in which neither side admitted liability and all claims and counterclaims were dismissed.  The Santa Cruz surf shops continue to print T-shirts
column10: and the Visitor's Bureau retains the right to use the trademark. In 2009 Steve Marble
column11: of Los Angeles Times' L.A. Now news blog
column12: wrote an article The real Surf City? It's Santa Cruz
column13: says magazine saying: "But Surfer magazine proclaims Santa Cruz to be 'The Real Surf City
column16: food and vibe of the nations' best known surf towns."  Steve Marble quotes Surfer: "Huntington Beach may have won the right to the name ‘Surf City
column18: but any surfer who's ever paddled out at Steamer Lane knows the judge got it wrong."
